div.p: THE WILD YOUTH: A COMEDY FOR DIGESTION, IN THREE ACTS. TRANSLATED FROM THE GERMAN OF KOTZEBUE, BY CHARLES SMITH.
NEW-YORK: PRINTED FOR CHARLES SMITH AND S. STEPHENS. 1800.

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.

list.item: JOHN MOLKUS, an Invalid with a wooden leg.

div.p: SCENE—A Hall in an Inn, with a middle door, and ſeveral ſide doors, which are numbered.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: FREDERICK ſtanding with folded arms before a door, and looking at the number.
div.p: NUMBER three—an ominous number—one is tempted to become a Pythagorean—but I ſhall not ſtir from this place, till I know who lives here—a female figure, as beautiful as if Angelica Kaufman An unrivalled German female painter. had been breathing her upon canvaſs— wife or maiden?—Oh, a maiden I am ſure! at church ſhe never turns her eye from the preacher: and when I meet her eye, her cheeks begin to glow like apple blossoms—In the end it's all the ſame—Frederick! Frederick! you lie (pointing to his heart) Here is ſomething moving: May ſhe be a girl!— a girl unengaged and free!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: LISETTE comes to the door and calls,

sp.p: Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (behind the ſcene) Here!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Bring coffee! (goes off again.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Directly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A pert thing. The chambermaid I ſuppoſe: I muſt throw a handful of money in her pocket.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Where art thou going?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Thou?—I have not drank fellowſhip with any one.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do not take it amiſs, where are you carrying the coffee?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: To number three.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who lives in number three?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: To-day ſuch a one, to-morrow another, as it happens at inns.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Fool! I will know—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Sir! if one man knows ſomething, and another wants to know it, he must pay for it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Juſt enough. There are three florins—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well! a reaſonable queſtion deſerves an anſwer. In number three there live three ladies.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who are they? what are their names? where are they going to? how long will they stay here?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I don't know: I don't know: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Don't you know their names?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Their names? yes, they are written in the town clerk's liſt.Every ſtranger that enters the gates of any town in Germany, is regiſtered.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The name of the old woman is Baroneſs Brumbach.Brumbach: the firſt ſyllable of this name ſignifies a growling or peeviſh perſon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The name augurs nothing good.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The name of the little wild girl is Liſette, her chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And that round angel's head?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What angel's head?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That Grecian girl, with the beautiful ſwan's neck, and the lily boſom?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I do not underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Blockhead, who is the third lady?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Blockhead? (he looks at the money in his hand) three florins—the blockhead may paſs.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The third lady is the young Baroneſs.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And her name?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well, her name is undoubtedly the same as her mothers.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Miſs Brumbach? fy, that can't be her name.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Give her another name then.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So I will, by God! I will—Do you know any thing more?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Nothing more, but that the coffee is getting cold.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Miſs Brumback, then?—fy! the name makes me ſhiver—but how can this beautiful girl help her hateful name? is it not in my power, to-day or to-morrow, to rebaptize her?—Baroneſs Wellinghorſt that ſounds better. If I knew only how to get acquainted with her? (he looks through the key-hole) I ſee a green ſofa, but no one ſits upon it—On the right hand a looking-glaſs, but no one is reflected by it—I muſt lurk a little— (as ſoon as he puts his eye to the key-hole, Liſette opens the door, and almoſt upſets him)

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (ſurpriſed) Oho! what's that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A formal ſiege, my pretty girl: but you make a ſally, and the enemy retreats.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Have I hurt you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, with your black eyes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: May I aſk with whom you wiſh to ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: With you, my dear girl.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: With me? well, I am here.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Tell me in whoſe ſervice you are?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: In Lady Brumbach's.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who is Lady Brumbach?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you aſk me what I can't anſwer. I am with her but three weeks, and of my predeceſſor I could learn nothing, for ſhe only ſtaid a fortnight with her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And you three weeks already? that does you credit.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My patience has already become as thin as a piece of thread, and if it was not for the dear miſs—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The dear miſs! true! the deareſt miſs!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I know but her, I have all my life time known nothing else.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Where have you ſeen her then?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yeſterday at church.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Never before?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (ſmiling) The acquaintance is ſhort indeed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am young, and the lady is young too, and in ſhort, I am mortally in love with her.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Aye, we don't know a word of that.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But I know it by heart.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Have you often ſuch attacks?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I muſt tell you, Liſette, that ever ſince my eighth year, I have been conſtantly in love, and I hope to be in love till my eightieth.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: The laſt object of your love will be to be envied.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The laſt is your young miſtreſs. I ſhall eternally love her.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Eternally?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Not an hour leſs.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well enough. Eternity is a fine little thing, eſpecially in the mouth of a young gentleman of twenty.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Twenty-one, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Twenty-one! I beg your pardon ſir. But may I not know the name of the knight errand whom my young lady has made her ſlave?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Baron Willinghorſt. I am rich, have neither father nor mother: to-morrow I ſhall be of age, and can do as I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: So, ſo, if only the young lady could do as ſhe pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Think you ſhe would be willing?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Why not? here an old ſcolding mother, there a young friendly gentleman, here a draught of rhubarb, there a glaſs of lemonade—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You enrapture me! I muſt kiſs you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (oppoſing him) Are you always accuſtomed to kiſs the chambermaid of your beloved, when you are enraptured?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Always, always, that's my way.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: The young ſparks kiſs, and the old ones pay.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh! on that ſubject I am a Methuſalem. (he gives her a purſe full of money) There little rogue.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (with feigned reſiſtance) No, no,—it was'nt meant ſo —indeed you are irreſiſtible.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Would to God your young lady was of the ſame opinion.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Who knows—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Tell her that I am languiſhing like Siegwart, and raving like Werter—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And love like Tom Jones.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That I am baſhful and modeſt—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: That you ſpout ſparks like a ſky-rocket.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Which at laſt diſſolve in balls of fire.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But the balls of fire extinguiſh.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dear child, we muſt not talk too long in ſimilies— Let us ſpeak of my gratitude, which is as eternal as my love.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I am contented with four weeks.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Jeſt aſide, you might put me in a grateful furor (he takes a letter from his pocket, which he turns about in his hands) If, for inſtance, you would—look at this letter.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Willingly (ſhe looks at it) it's a letter without a direction.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: It is from me, addreſſed through you to my future bride.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A bride without a name? I may then give it to whom I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Only not to the old lady Brumbach, keep it yourſelf rather.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: No my dear ſir of one and twenty years, we do not proceed in love as a letter does by poſt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The God of love is drawn by pigeons, and pigeons fly. As ſoon as he puts ſnails to his chariot I'll walk flower too.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My young lady does not know even that you exiſt, and is to enter in correſpondence with you. That's dangerous.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She has to read only.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: The letter is copied from your eyes, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Verbatim.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then I know it by heart already.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But an ambaſſador without credentials.—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Patience! patience!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This word is not in my dictionary.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then write it in it. Keep your tender letter. I ſhall tell her, that a handſome young gentleman, with a pair of large wild eyes, has reſolved to love her eternally. Not ſo?

sp.speaker: Fred
sp.p: The very thing.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: That he is a rich Baron, of age to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And that he would marry her the day after to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why not to-morrow evening?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: If but mamma is not too ſparing with her maternal bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Fred,
sp.p: Chance has made me a Baron, chance has given me two lordly eſtates: what can ſhe have againſt me?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: She will ſay, that children muſt not marry.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In a few years ſhe may tell that to our children.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A mother does not like to ſhare the myrtle crown with her daughter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What! is the old one going to marry a ſecond time?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A third time.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Bravo.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Her firſt huſband ſhe plagued to death, the ſecond is run away, but the third ſhe'll lock up more carefully.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Indeed? yet ſhe carries her young daughter about with her? ſhe wants to ſell cucumbers and has melons in her baſket.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: We imagine the melons are not yet ripe, we call miſs Nannette only the little girl, the child.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Miſs Nannette? is her name Nannette?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A lovely name. I am enraptured at the very name! I muſt kiſs you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Again?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If your young lady has half a dozen ſuch pretty names, I kiſs you ſix times more.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Be quiet, ſir! if we ſhould be overheard, they will think you are in love with me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why not? I am in love with you. I have been at one time, in love with eight girls

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A pretty recommendation!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I was but young then.

sp.speaker: Lsſ.
sp.p: To be ſure, conſtancy comes but with age.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But if you think a divided heart burns weaker, the fire of my kiſſes ſhall prove to you—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (oppoſing him) Baron! Baron!

sp.speaker: Felix.
sp.p: (ſtanding at the door) Frederick! Frederick!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Are you got up already, dear Mr. Felix.

sp.speaker: Felix.
sp.p: I might aſk you that. You are always aſleep ſome hours longer than I.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah! love robs me of ſleep.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Again? three miles from here it was the ſame caſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Three miles? juſt three? that's ominous.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Look at number three at the door there.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There lives my beloved.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: What! ſhe who juſt now went away?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That's the chambermaid only. A ſtar of the ſixth rank to the ſun.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I am uſed to your ſuns and angels.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Felix, if Mahomet could put the moon in his ſleeves, I ſhall be able to marry the ſun.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You will burn your wings.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You jeſt, but I am perfectly in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: God forbid.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Becauſe we find of twenty marriages ſcarcely one that's tolerable, and of an hundred but one that is happy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are a woman hater.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: A burnt child dreads the fire, but a youth will throw himſelf into the flames.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What a ſweetneſs there is in burning.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I know it, and have paid dear enough for my experience▪

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Only think, her name is Nannette.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And if her name was Angelica—a name does not make an angel.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She is ſcarcely ſixteen.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: The longer ſhe will torment you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She is beautiful like a roſe.

sp.speaker: Fel
sp.p: The more admirers will ſurround her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She is mild like a pigeon.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Women are all ſo, but out of he houſe only.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well then we ride out all day.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My young friend, you make a jeſt of the moſt ſerious occurrence of your life.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Juſt the contrary; I think it to be the moſt pleaſant. To love a beautiful girl, to be beloved by her, to marry her; what more pleaſant can there be?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: It's enough that I know you, and that I know how quick your ſparks extinguiſh.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Becauſe they were ſparks: but now it is a Trojan fire.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Dear Frederick, leave off theſe romances. You know the world, you have at my ſide travelled through all Europe, and have seen ſomething more than inns.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, dear Mr. Felix, I have to thank you for my knowledge of man.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You know men, and don't know yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The ſeven ſages of Greece were not a breadth of hair the better off.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And if you have poſſeſſed your Nannette a twelve-month—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then I have paſſed three hundred and ſixty-five happy days.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And in the ſecond year—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A day more, if it is a leap-year.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: May my own terrible example ſerve you as a warning. I was alſo married, and am perhaps ſtill.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Perhaps? There is not much of tenderneſs in this perhaps?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p:
I played a romance with my wife. I gazed with her at
the moon, inſtead of looking into her heart; and at the ſunſhine of reaſon I found that I was moſt egregiouſly miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then you opened your Zenophon, and read the life of Socrates.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My Xantippe daily offered me the cup of poiſon. Vanity, obſtinacy, and the damnable ſcandal at laſt drove me out of my houſe into the wide world.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You left her then.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: It was wrong. I confeſs to you my weakneſſes, to prevent you from falling into the ſame. I left 〈◊〉 all my property, and my daughter; took nothing with me, but the little knowledge I have acquired.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Particularly knowledge of women.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My adopted name Felix protected me from all enquiry, and ſo I came to your father's houſe, when you were but an infant.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Poor man! why have you not called yourſelf Infelix?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Your father's friendſhip, your genius, and the goodneſs of your heart, have theſe twelve years eaſed my grief.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My father died and left to me the duty of indemnifying you for his friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You can do it if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: We muſt always remain together.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: If my age will not be troubleſome to you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I could never be quite happy without your company.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I love you as my ſon, and warn you as my ſon. Your father's laſt words ſound ſtill in my ears.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Follow this man, he ſaid to me, and my bleſſing will be upon you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You will be of age to-morrow, and I have no more command over you. You are maſter of your fortune and your perſon. A friend dare only requeſt and caution.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A friend? you make me proud of this title—but my dear Mr. Felix! why ſhould I be unhappy in my marriage becauſe you was ſo in yours?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I don't ſay ſo. Many a one has drawn the higheſt prize; but let that romantic fire once be vaniſhed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That may laſt long. I have lately been at the theatre, when Iſland's Bachelor was performed, and poor Reinhold moved me ſo that I reſolved at once to marry.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You are much too young.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Youth can be contented eaſier.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: And eaſier be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Whoever chooſes forty years, does not always chooſe well.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You do not know the object of your love. You have ſeen a book in Engliſh binding, and do not know its contents.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Should God have given to a bad book ſo fine a binding?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: An hour of reflection is better than a year of repentance.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Right, dear Mr. Felix, I will put Nannette to the proof with all the caution of a lover.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: (ſmiling) That's all, to be ſure, that a lover can promiſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In the firſt place, I have wrote her this letter, in which I tell her I adore her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: The beſt manner to acquire knowledge of her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If I but knew how to get the letter into her hands.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: In time we gather roſes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But when the roſes are once in bloſſom there is no time to be loſt.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You have called me your friend. Well, make uſe of my eyes. Love has put ſpectacles on my noſe.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Is love then a dealer in ſpectacles; or is it better to borrow a microſcope from a hypocondriac? he that breaks the ſpectacles of any man, deſerves very little thanks—But, patience! you ſhall ſee Nannette, and be bewitched by her yourſelf. Her ſoft blue eyes, her modeſt graces, her amiable baſhfulneſs, her attractive innocence—formed like a Grecian, blooming like a Circaſſian, the boſom of a Turkiſh, and the teeth of a Mooriſh beauty— (A ſervant girl with a bunch of keys, paſſes over
the ſtage: Frederick perceives her)
Halt! halt! what a neat creature!—hear, dear little one, do'nt run ſo faſt! Little ſatan! can you not wait?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: There we have it! each white apron puts him in flames. Thoughtleſs youth! you miſtake youthful flames for love; woe to the poor girl that throws her myrtle garland into ſuch ſtraw flames.

sp.speaker: Liſette.
sp.p: (counting the money which Frederick gave her) eight dollars and a piece of gold. This young gentleman pleaſes me. He is as briſk as a cornet, and as generous as a prince. Let us ſee what a reaſonable chambermaid has to do in ſuch a caſe. Here burns the fire and there lays the ſtraw. She has but to move the ſtraw a little nearer the fire, and to blow a little into it, then the buſineſs is finiſhed.

sp.speaker: Nannette
sp.p: (appears) Has mamma got up?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: O yes, ſhe is juſt combing her lap-dog.

sp.speaker: Nannette.
sp.p: (Gaping) What day is to-day?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Monday.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am ſorry.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Becauſe we are ſo far from Sunday.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Has the laſt ſermon pleaſed you ſo much?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: The ſermon? Oh no? but at church we ſee people. The whole week we dare not think of going out.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: We ſee and are ſeen.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Who would look on my indifferent hat, and my plain white gown? Indeed, I am aſhamed. Mamma gives me nothing better.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Mamma Nature has been the more generous to you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: When I ſet among the fine dreſſed ladies, I feel, that Mamma is in the right.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: She always calls me a ſtupid ugly thing.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: There are people, who would ſwear to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Yes, Baron Piffelburg told me once that I was handſome, but mamma grew angry, and then he retracted.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I know a young gentleman who would not retract, if mamma was to become ten times as angry.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Do you know him? how happy you are! you know ſo many people.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I know him ſince half an hour only, but he prattled ſo much of you, that I could talk ſix months of it.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Of me? tell me dear Liſette, tell.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: He is young, well made, ardent in love—

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: In love? with whom?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: With Miſs Nannette.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: With me! Oh my God! how you frightened me!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: With what?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: We muſt immediately acquaint mamma of it.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Aye, indeed!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You jeſt with me.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Not at all, he wants to marry you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Marry me? I fall in a ſwoon.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: No matter for that.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Tell me, can I then indeed be married already?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Why not? if you meet with a good match?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: You make me laugh.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: He is rich, and beſides a nobleman:

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Are then noblemen ſo amiable?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Not always, but I lay a wager this one will pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If he loves me, you win the wager.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: When I told him that your name was Nannette, he became ſo enraptured, that he embraced me.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Was that a token of his love too?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Very ſingular; I do not like that.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: He deſired of me to carry a letter to you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Quick, quick, where is it?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Aye, aye, would that be becoming? I have ſcolded him well for it.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Fy, that was ſtupid of you. No one has ever wrote to me yet?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: We muſt firſt know him better.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Now the poor young man will be grieved.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: No danger; grief does not ſeem to be his buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: But what will be the end of it?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Time brings advice. Mamma will ſtay here for ſome time yet, for the romance with Baron Piffelburg begins to become ſerious. An opportunity will preſent itſelf to ſee and converſe with each other.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: To ſee and converſe? What do you think? I could n't lift an eye, nor ſpeak a word.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: That's his look out. Who knows what may happen. He has fine eſtates, and if you become Baroneſs Wellinghorſt, I accompany you and marry his ſteward.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Yes, but—then he ſhall not embrace you any more.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Silence! Mamma is coming.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (kiſſing her hand) Good morning, dear mamma.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Good morning little thing. My God! how you look again this morning: Well and blooming like a maid ſervant.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I ſlept very well.

sp.speaker: Brum
sp.p: But you are not to ſleep well. It is not becoming a young girl of quality to ſleep all night like a mountain rat.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: After ſupper I can never keep my eyes open.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: That's a ruſtic cuſtom, (ſitting down at the table.) A lady of education knows how to be ſick becomingly, and I have thank God, not had a healthy hour all my life time.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A certain languiſhing ſoftneſs has, thereby, ſpread itſelf over your whole frame.—

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: Men are tytants. How could we ſo often trample under our feet the rights of the ſtronger, if we did not know how to render our weakneſs intereſting. Weak nerves, cramps, Pyrmont water in the ſummer, and Baldrian pills in the winter, has converted many a boiſterous huſband into a pleaſant companion.— However, theſe maternal advices are too ſoon for you. Go, child, go to my cabinet; read the morning prayers and take Mops on your lap. I have to ſpeak to Liſette. (Exit Nannette.)

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: The poor fellow! inquietude would not let him reſt? What do you think, Liſette, ſhall I marry him.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: This queſtion, my lady, you muſt direct to your heart.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: God forbid! I am glad the times are paſſed, in which the heart plays the maſter, and throws duſt in the eyes of reaſon. Love is a good ſlave, but a bad maſter. Marrying is a bad cuſtom, which one muſt comply with like the Sieſta in Spain. But woe to the fool that bends her neck, when ſhe is born to command.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: With Baron Piffelburg—

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: Is not that running a riſk? but even that is in his favor. A woman cannot appear in the world with decency, if ſhe does not always carry an animal in man's cloath with her, and this Piffelburg may do as well as any other. His eſtate, to be ſure, is involved, but he is of an old family and a very honeſt fellow. A certain poliſh, a certain fine feeling, we miſs in him; ſo much the better! nature! nature! nothing excels nature!—Liſette, where are my teeth?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: They lay in your apartment.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: This man ſeems really attached to me. However, I ſhall put his obedience to the teſt.—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And if he anſwers the teſt?

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: I am tired of roving alone about in the world. I want a huſband who can keep my accounts and quarrel with poſtillions and innkeepers. Beſides, I have to provide for a little child—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Have you got a little child yet?

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: My God, have you forgot Nannette?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Miſs Nannette—

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: What Miſs! ſhe is a child that ſcarcely knows the right hand from the left. I hope you are not putting ſtuff into her head—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: God forbid! ſhe hardly knows that ſhe has a head.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: There we have it. A mother's care is a very heavy care. Beſides, there is Mops, the Canary birds—nothing can be truſted to you domeſtics. My future huſband will have his hands full.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You might eaſily get rid of the care of Miſs Nannette.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Give her a huſband, the firſt the beſt.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: Are you crazy? hah! hah! hah! this child a huſband! We do not marry our girls as the Ruſſians do their boys.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But if one could be found, who would take her—

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: Hold your tongue! Early marriage, late repentance. When the daughters feel the mother's muſt think. Hymen led by the god of love, is a Moloch, to whom I ſhall never ſacrifice my child.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I ſhould pity poor Mops, for he is ſo much attached to Miſs Nannette.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: For that very reaſon. No, as long as poor Mops is alive, Nannette dare not think of marrying.

sp.speaker: A Servant
sp.p: (enters) Baron Piffelburg wiſhes to be admitted.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: He is welcome.—Go, Liſette, let us be alone.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide). The ſhepherd's hour is at hand.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Lady BRUMBACH. Baron PIFFELBURG in a hunting habit.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Good luck to you. Lady! a freſh morning. I have been wetting my feet in the dew.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You ſpeak as pathetical as if you had read Kleiſt or Thompſon.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Kleiſt? my couſin ſerves in that regiment. Thompſon is the miller's name on my eſtate. The raſcal is a deer ſtealer.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Have you a good hunting ground?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: The beſt in the country. Marry me, and you ſhall ſee a hunting match or a fox chaſe—You are old, madam, but I'll be ſhot if you have ſeen any thing like it, all your life time.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: It ſeems, Baron, as if you underſtood as much of a woman's age as of the Chineſe language.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: You are right, I ſpeak German.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Quite maſſive German.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: The age of a horſe I can determine to a hair, I have to look at the teeth only.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Won't you go down into the ſtable?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: What am I to do there? the inn-keeper has a pair of the age of twenty—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Your language will be better underſtood there.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Have I again been guilty of a ſtupid action? D'ont take it amiſs, I am plain and ſtreight, but I mean it as honeſt as my pointer.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Indeed, if one is not acquainted with your language—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: What matters language, if but the heart has its charge? make once an end of it, madam, give me your hand. To-morrow ſhall be our wedding, and the next day the fox-chaſe.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What are you thinking? at my age—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: For that very reaſon, neither of us has any time to loſe. I am an old boy too!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: My God! how old do you take me to be?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Have you not told me that your ſecond huſband was killed in the ſeven years war?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Why not at the Trojan conflagration?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: What of war! of conflagration, I love peace, and would marry you, even if you had gone to ſchool with Methuſalem: Well, then, madam, make no difficulties. Come with me to Piffelburg. My paſtor ſhall publiſh the bans from the pulpit, and then in the name of God: be fruitful and multiply.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Not ſo raſh, Mr. huntſman,. To kill a partridge, and to gain a woman, are two different things.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Have I not long enough watched for the game; I think it is time to chaſe it.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (aſide) Stop, I'll ſound my power, and heat your head a little. (loud) There is nothing more unſufferable than to conclude a marriage like a bargain of merchandize: where nothing of juvenile thoughtleſſneſs is intermixed either by duel or ſuicide, either by night or elopement.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: But, hang it, with whom am I to fight then? whom ſhall I elope with?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Our romance ſhall not end ſo tragical, but thouſand other things are to be conſidered—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Thouſand? that's a great deal. Begin then.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And thouſand little manners to be obſerved—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul! in this I am a novice.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: We muſt be alone.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Who interrupts us then?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Can we not every moment be ſurpriſed by my daughter or my chambermaid?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Well, then we ſend them back.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: That is againſt decency. Do you know what? yonder door leads into the garden. Here is the key to it. At midnight▪ the hour of ghoſts, I expect you here.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: At midnight! pſhaw! the wild huntſmanAlluding to a German ſtory, of the ghoſt of a dead huntſman rioting in the foreſts. riots then.-

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I hope you are not afraid?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: No, no, but I may overſleep myſelf.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Then you may to-morrow ſeek for a ſweetheart in the dew.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: But why am I to come juſt through the garden? this houſe is a hotel, it is open all night, nobody prevents me from coming in.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Will you expoſe my name?—and then the garden, the freſh air, the ſong of the nightingales—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: The nightingales d'ont ſing now.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: In ſhort, ſir, through the garden is the way to my heart.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Well, well, I did'nt know that your heart was a garden houſe.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Go, the compariſon is not a bad one; a garden-houſe, an arbour, faintly brightened by the light of the moon—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: The moon does not ſhine now.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: We paſs in the cool through the 〈◊〉 walks—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: We ſhall catch cold.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A lover muſt not ſhun a conſumption even—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: If I looſe my uſual night's reſt, I am not worth a ſhot of powder the whole day.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: So much the better. There is no merit without a ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I think, madam, we ſhould leave ſuch triflings to young people. If we add your age and mine together, the product will exceed a century—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: This man will make a Cybela of me.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: We both have the gout.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Your mind is terribly deranged.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I am plagued with the hip, and you are ſometimes ſhort-breathed.—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: My God!—how am I—I am falling in a ſwoon—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: There we have it! and yet ſhe wants to walk about at night.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Nannette!—Liſette!—I die—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: No danger. Swallow a handful of gun-powder.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Nannette!—Liſette!— help! help!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: What's the matter with you, dear mamma?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: My ſalts—give me my ſalts.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (holds it to her noſe) I am ſure the young Baron Piffelburg has taken liberties.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: What young Baron Piffelburg! I am an old man (half aſide) and ſhe is too changing into wiſdom, as the Ruſſian hares in the winter ſeaſon do into whiteneſs.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Get out of my ſight!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: (aſide) Rot it, ſhe is getting angry. (loud) Dear creature, I did'nt mean to offend you.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Away with you, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Remember the beautiful Duet in the Coſa rara. Let us make peace—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A charming Lubino!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I'll ſend an excellent hog into your kitchen.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Go to the devil with your hog.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: upon my ſoul, it is becoming ſerious!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Don't you hear? you are to go.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but may I not come again?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Never, no more!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Well, well, I know what I have to do, and if that fails, I ſound a retreat, and couple the hounds. Exit.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Is he gone indeed? without throwing himſelf at my feet?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You will excuſe him, he is a little ſtiff.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Ah! how much have we to excuſe in men!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear mamma, do the Ruſſian hares get white in the winter?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You are a gooſe.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If my lover was to tell me ſuch things, I would give him up inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Is it poſſible! what do I hear! the infants in the cradle will ſoon babble to each other: I love you! each puppet will be an amor, and each ſugar cake a love letter. Miſs Pertneſs! Do you then know the beings, who are called lovers?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Not yet ſo exactly.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Let us hear what conception you have of them?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: A lover is a creature—which I like very well.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Right miſs, one cannot define it.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Beware, child, of a lover, more than of the ſpring ſun: The one only ſpoils the ſkin, the other the heart.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And if he don't ſpoil it, he takes it away.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: One might ſwear that it was made for that.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A lover is a cunning being, which will take advantage of your weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Are we then weak when we have a lover?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: That happens ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Like a ſlave he will lay at your feet. Let him lay.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: The poor creature!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: If you raiſe him up, he is your tyrant.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: The rogue!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A lover is a ſecond Proteus, he will inſinuate himſelf in all kinds of ſhape.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: FREDERICK, (dreſſed like a hair-dreſſer, with a powder-bag under his arm, puts his head into the door.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I beg pardon▪ do I come right here?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (laughing) Indeed in all manner of ſhape.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Whom are you looking for, my friend?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am looking for the amiable Baroneſs Brumbach.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I am the ſame, but ſpeak with reverence.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In my country, love and reverence are inſeparable.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide to Nannette) Miſs, this is the young Baron.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (cries) Ah!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What ails you?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Nothing, dear mamma.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You frightened her ſo much about the lovers.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Muſt I then run away when I ſee one?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Yes, if I am not preſent.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In this country children become knowing very early.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, my friend, but what's your deſire?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I wiſh to have the honor to put your ſilken locks into curls.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You have taken this trouble in vain: I have a hair-dreſſer.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Quite right, he is my employer: he has been taken ſick, and ſends me inſtead of him.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: So, ſo, what ails him then?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: He—has broke his leg.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Poor man: how did that happen?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: He went up the ſteeple of St. Ann's Church, on his return he glided and fell down ſeventy-ſeven feet.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he that climbs high falls low—Liſette give me my dreſſing-gown.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (bringing the dreſſing-gown.) My friend, have you been a long while at this trade?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I hope ſoon to be maſter— (begins dreſſing)

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then you'll marry, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (looking ſtealingly at Nannette) O yes, if my love is not rejected.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What countryman are you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am an emigrant from Alſace, if I am found out I am loſt.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You muſt take care.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I take all poſſible pains to deceive all thoſe, who want to be deceived.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You are right. Have you many cuſtomers in this city?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I forget them all when I am with you, Baroneſs.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You are a droll. Do you dreſs the Baroneſs Hengſtburg?—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Baroneſs Hengſtburg? O yes

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: How old do you think that lady may be?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Baroneſs Hengſtburg?—how old?— You, my lady, might be her daughter.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (ſmiling) Not ſo old. She is a few years younger than I.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is it poſſible! (he ſhows Nannette his letter—Liſette takes it and gives it to her.)

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: But it is natural that ſhe looks ſo old. Irregular living.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If I was her huſband, I would keep her ſhort.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: She is a widow.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: True, ſhe is a widow.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: No, they are ſeparated.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Or ſeparated, the ſame thing.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: To my room.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Stay, you have nothing to do there.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Has the revolution driven you from your country?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To my ſorrow! they wanted to force liberty upon me and (caſting a glance on Nannette) I love ſervitude ſo much—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Hair-dreſſers are the ſlaves of luxury.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I intended to fly to England, but ſince Pitt has laid a tax upon hair-powder, not much is to be gained there.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Liſette give me— (turning her head ſhe perceives Nanette reading) he—miſs, what have you got there?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (frightened) Nothing, dear mamma.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Nothing? I will ſee it: Here with it!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: It is—it is—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: It is a paper—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Will you obey?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah! moſt likely the letter I had in my powder-bag.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What letter?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your roguiſh chambermaid, I dare ſay, has ſtole it out of the bag.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You might have choſen a more civil expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Shall I ſoon be informed of the thing in queſtion?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Between us, madam, but you muſt not betray me, it is a letter to the Baroneſs Hengſtberg.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: To that lady? Let me ſee it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: When I dreſſed her hair this morning I found it upon her toilet.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: How imprudent!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And in that inſtant it was in my bag. With your permiſſion I'll read it to you.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Read my friend. Go to your room, Nannette.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why? the young miſs will not underſtand any thing of it.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Children ſhould not hear ſuch things. Yet you may ſtay to draw good advice from it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (reads, throwing glances at Nannette) "My dear amiable creature!"

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Very fine! ſhe has grey eyes, and freckles in her face.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (reads) "I ſaw you but once, but my heart is yours forever."

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: The fool! what is his name?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The letter has no ſignature.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Read on.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (reads) "When you came from church yeſterday"—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: From church! that woman never goes to church.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (reads) "at the ſide of your ugly old mother."—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: True, her mother is an ugly old woman, and as malicious as a cat.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And as vain as a peacock.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And as ſtupid as a gooſe.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Malicious, vain and ſtupid, an excellent picture ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Fred. and Liſ.
sp.p: ha! ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (reads) "I am young, rich, and in love with you."

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Three fine things.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (reads) "I love you inexpreſſibly."

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: My God! it becomes quite flat.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (reads) "Give your hand to a young man, who means it honeſt."

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A lover's honeſty is ſuſpicious.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (reads) "Whoſe birth is equal to yours, and who will deliver you from your mother's tyranny."

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I d'ont know that. The mother complies with every thing, her daughter wants.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: "Let us try to deceive your mother."

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: That's not very difficult.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: "And if all is in vain, then you fly to the arms of him who adores you."

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Even an elopement? This was yet wanting?— How I ſhall laugh at the old woman! —Is that tender pallaver at an end?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable more.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But I think the young gentleman has been very explicit.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Very explicit.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: He has, indeed, if even you have underſtood it.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: What would you ſay, miſs Nannette, if ſuch a letter was written to you?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I would not ſuffer my mother to be made a jeſt of.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then you would reject the ardent youth.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Not juſt that.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: How can you put the poor child in ſuch a confuſion?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I am confuſed indeed, dear mamma.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And ſo Baroneſs Hengſtburg entertains a ſecret correſpondence with a young unknown one.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I know who he is.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Well? quick!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A certain Baron Wellinghorſt.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Baron Wellinghorſt? aye! aye! at our tea-party this evening, I muſt communicate it to four of my moſt intimate friends.

sp.speaker: Hair-Dreſſer.
sp.p: Madam, your moſt humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: My God, ſir, have you not broke your leg?

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: Broke my leg?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Did you not get upon the ſteeple of St. Ann's church?

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: Upon St. Ann's ſteeple?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: And fell down ſeven and ſeventy feet?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But you might have broke your leg?

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: Might have broke my leg?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This time he got off with a bruiſe.

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: With a bruiſe? I do not underſtand a word of all that.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Why then have you ſent your journeyman to me?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (winking to him) My dear maſter have you not ordered me to dreſs this lady?

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: Not at all! as long as I have a ſound pair of legs I can ſerve my cuſtomers myſelf.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But you do not dreſs hair with your legs—

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: This fellow is an impoſter.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (tries to put ſome money in his hands) You do not underſtand me right.

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: There is nothing to underſtand. I ſee you are a ſtupid fellow, where are your cuſtomers?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (endeavors again to put money into his hands) — Here, here.

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: Nothing here! I have a few ſixpences yet to drink a pot of beer with.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (aſide) I am frightened to death!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: He is then not in your employ?

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: No more than your Mops. He is an impoſter, a vagrant.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Young fellow! what has put it into your head, to intrude yourſelf into my houſe?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (collecting himſelf) Well, I will confeſs it: I am an unfortunate youth—I ſaw you, madam!—I ſaw you! —is not that ſaying all?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And what is that to ſignify?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If love is a crime, then may he pardon me who made my heart ſo feeling and you ſo charming!—I was ſeized with the moſt violent paſſion, yet I did not loſe ſight of modeſty. The only wiſh I had was to ſee you, to be near you. I meditated on the means, and fell upon this innocent diſguiſe; But my lips would never have uttered, what forever may drive me from your preſence. (he kneels down) Puniſh me now! puniſh in me the power of your attractions!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: My friend, you either tell a lie, or you are a fool. Get up, I pardon you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (riſes) Ah! I muſt be gone! (with a glance at Nannette) but my heart remains behind!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Who tells you that you are to go? You are a young good for nothing fellow, who might be mended by reaſonable correction—You ſee, dear Mr. Hairdreſſer, that nothing can be done with this young man.

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: Nothing be done? he muſt go to Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: If I excuſe his boldneſs you may do the ſame.

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip does not loſe a ſingle cent by it, but he quacks into my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: In ſhort, maſter, there is your money. I have a right to be dreſſed by whom I pleaſe; I take this young man into my ſervice, as valet de chambre.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (kiſſes her hand with extacy) You reſtore me to life again.

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: But he does not underſtand hairdreſſing. Only ſee how he towzed your hair.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: That's nothing to you. Be off!

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: Take care, young fellow, I ſhall complain to the police of you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: D'ont you hear? you are to go.

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: I ſhall get you drummed out of town.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Drum my valet de chambre out of the city?— you ruſſian!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: He is a fool!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: An unpoliſhed fellow!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: An envious raſcal!

sp.speaker: Hairdr.
sp.p: You are a bread thief! a good-for-nothing rogue!

sp.speaker: Fred. and Liſ.
sp.p: (puſhing him towards the door) Go! go! out with you!

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: In that moment Piffelburg enters, behind him a huntſman with half a dozen hares. Frederick and Liſette throw the hair-dreſſer upon Piffelburg, who puſhes him upon the huntſman, and the latter throws him out of the door.)

sp.speaker: Hairdreſſer.
sp.p: (crying out) A cheat! a cheat!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: What is the fellow talking? are theſe not freſh hares, killed this morning?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You return already, ſir?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Yes, madam, and what am I bringing with me? he?— —half a dozen hares, as peace-makers between you and me.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Your price of peace is ſlender indeed.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I think ſix hares—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And a Bear into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: There are no bears in this country.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: If I knew that true repentance had led you to my feet.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: To be ſure, my deareſt, here they all lay at your feet.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The moſt repentant hares in the world.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: My God! the animals ſtink!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: How can they ſtink, they have only been ſhot this morning?—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And the gentleman has been ſhot too.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Young man, you take a little too much liberty for a valet de chambre.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: A valet de chambre? (he looks at him attentively) hail and lightning! are you not the young Baron, in whoſe company I was laſt evening at the coffee-houſe?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A Baron?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I at the coffee-houſe? ah! my God! I am ſometimes glad if I can get a drink of ſmall beer.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I am damn'd if it is'nt you! Did we not drink three bowls of punch together?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, ſir.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Have we not been very merry together?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: God knows who made himſelf merry with you.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Did you not ſay, that a beautiful young lady lived here in this inn, who had an ugly old mother? Did you not call the mother an old beaſt? Did you not drink the young lady's health?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Heavens! could it be poſſible?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide) Now we are in a pretty pickle!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: (aſide) I die!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are blind, ſir.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I blind? I have even this morning ſhot four hares?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Blind! blind! I tell you! blind! blind! blind! (he powders his whole face full and runs away.)

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: (ſhaking himſelf) hell and damnation!—Baron! I am a nobleman—a huntſman—We muſt ſee each other with piſtols!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: How am I?—my eyes become open— Such an affront to me—I fall in a ſwoon!—

sp.speaker: Piff
sp.p: The fellow is a deer-ſtealer, he wanted to hunt upon ſtrange ground.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I die!—Where is my faithful friend?—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Here! here!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: The only one who never deceived me!—My Mops—My laſt conſolation?— (ſhe goes ſlowly towards her apartment)

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: May I accompany you?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (weak and faintly) Go to the devil! Exit.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Then I muſt go with you.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I ſhall tell my mother of that.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: So miſs, and who is the cauſe of all this chaſe? a ſprightly young huntſman has traced your ſcent, and follows you through buſh and wood—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And an old hunter cries halloo! that the game runs off. Is that right?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: No, that's not right.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well, then, young lady, we leave this gentleman in good company, ſhe points to the hares and goes off with Nannette.

sp.speaker: PIFFELBURG
sp.p: Here they leave me alone like a mill-ſtone, and powdered like a hare in the ſnow. Thunder and lightning! If the old one had not plenty of dollars, I'll be damn'd if I ever would put my foot again upon this hunting-ground, where an honeſt fellow remains ſticking in ſwamp and moraſs. What is to be done! One may ſhoot a crow, that carries gold to his neſt—I ſhall have to make uſe of the garden key, to open the money cheſt with it. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: LISETTE, coming from the bedchamber, and going to the middle door, calls out,

sp.p: MOLKUS!

sp.speaker: Molkus.
sp.p: (behind the ſcene) Here!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (lamentable) Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (appears) What is it?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (more lamentable) Dear Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (quite friendly and cheerful) Good day to you.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Nothing elſe?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Is a good day nothing?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Nothing in your mouth.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then may heaven give you the worſt day▪

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: As bad as the day on which you loſt your leg.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: 'Twas my day of honor.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! men are fooliſh beings. A ſoldier looſes a leg—that's his day of honor. A girl bends her neck to the yoke of matrimony—that's her day of honor. A nun takes the veil—that's her day of honor. The firſt receives a medal, the ſecond a huſband, and the third nothing at all. It's a good thing that putting on of foolſcaps has got out of faſhion. Every man is a fool; is it not true, Molkus?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Not true.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: The wooden legg'd look down upon the ſtrait legg'd, the ſtrait legg'd upon the bendy legg'd, and the bendy legg'd again upon the wooden legg'd.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Balderdaſh! (he is going)

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I am going!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Do you know then what I have to tell you?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: D'ont you want to know it?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But you ſhall know it. Lady Brumbach orders you to wait for her here, ſhe is going to take an airing in her carriage.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But ſhe is not well—No—Well!— What anſwers are theſe?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Short ones.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Do you meaſure your anſwers by your ſhort leg?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Do you know what, my friend, get your head ſhot away too, you have as little uſe for it as for your leg.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I do not always talk with women.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Blockhead! What then do the men want generally in women's company?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Every thing but a head.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And if it was not for the women, my God, who then would put your heads to rights?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I can.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Do but hear, how the lovely young lady flatters you.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And the lovely mother growls.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Is it then all in vain?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But you must be hungry? There are some almond cakes.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I eat ammunition bread.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well, then come down into the kitchen, to have a bit of roast beef with it.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: It's too soon yet.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: It grows dark already.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Do you know where that comes from?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Because the evening is approaching.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And do you know, why you are a blockhead?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Because you are all darkness, night in your head, and midnight in your heart.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: So?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: What is to be done with the blockhead?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: (flattering him) You are an honest fellow, dear Molkus.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: To your sorrow. Is it not so?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then we may converse without compliments.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Without compliments.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Tell me then, do you relish your pipe?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But do you know, where we properly ought to smoke?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Where we relish it.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: No, in the guard room. (She knocks his pipe from his mouth)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (takes it up again coolly) If you do that again—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well, and what then?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Then I pick it up again.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Dear, damnable Molkus! Pray get a little in a passion at least.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Anger is hurtful.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Nothing hurts you, my iron Molkus: you may get angry without danger, my wooden-door-post. Place yourself in the cornfield, my dear straw-man, and drive the birds away.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: That's what I am just doing.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You remain faithful to your post, like a painted soldier over a door. You have the spirit of a lump of lead, and the heart of a chained dog.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And you are witty like a chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Tell me, in how many battles you ran away?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ran away?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: It can't be otherwise; you must have run away, for all your sensibility was in your leg. When it was shot away, the blockish stump remained motionless on the ground, but, I am sure, the leg was long convulsed like that of a spider.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: You are a poisonous spider.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Immoveable blockhead! do you think we are sultanesses? And you suffer yourself to be placed as a miserable Harem's guard?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I know which part of your body cannot be wounded.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Your lungs.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: It is not worth while to speak to you.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Then let me alone.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You neither hear nor see, neither taste nor feel; you can only smell your stinking tobacco.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The tobacco is not bad.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Come Miss, let us leave this unpolished fellow. He is worse than an oister, that has even not two senses.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Are you there, Molkus?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Here?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I ſhall go to my Milliner, for half an hour.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You ſee here two fooliſh girls.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: But that wild impudent boy, who is after one of theſe girls, you do'nt ſee.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: He moſt likely will make uſe of my abſence. If he comes, I order you to throw him out.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Through the door or the window?

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: Where you like.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Brum.
sp.p: (to Nannette) You ſilly thing, you read meanwhile in the works of Madame de Beaumont, or Mad. de Ce • lis.— pour former le coeur and l'eſprit. You Liſette, take care of Mops.

sp.speaker: Molkus.
sp.stage: (puts a chair before the door▪ ſits upon it▪ takes a ſhort tobacco pipe out of his pocket, fills it, and ſtrikes fire.)

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You do not aſk, whether we like the ſmell of tobacco?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Miſs, pray fall in a ſwoon a little.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Juſt as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I d'ont underſtand that yet, I muſt learn it from mamma.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: This would be the fineſt opportunity to ſpeak to your lover.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: He certainly is not far off.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Methinks I feel it.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: How can we get rid of this blockhead?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Give him good words.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I would rather give them to Mops, he wags his tail at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: We will both try it—Dear Molkus—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Charming Molkus!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What elſe?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You ſit very uncomfortable.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: It's very well.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: An old meritorious ſoldier like you, ſhould be carried on hands.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: A wooden leg is better than a woman's hand.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: In my lady's apartment ſtands a very ſoft ſofa.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Let it ſtand there.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: We will conduct you there.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then I fetch from under the bed the bottle with the Dantzic cordials.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I am not dry.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You deſerve to have your likeneſs engraved, on account of your honeſty.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Glazed and framed.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then we will hang you under the looking-glaſs.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Ah! I wiſh you were hanging there already.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide) or at the gallows.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Let me ſtep out a moment to the balcony.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: To take a little freſh air, we are here almoſt ſuffocated with ſmoke.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: 'Tis not ſo bad.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Dear, charming Molkus, can you refuſe me any thing?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I have two senses, for I just hear the knocking at the door.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Then get up, and go out. (the knocking is repeated.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Get up? Yes—but to go out? No. (he gets up and puts his head through the door) Who is there?

sp.speaker: A rough voice on the outſide.
sp.p: A friend!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What friend?

sp.speaker: The voice.
sp.p: An old invalid wants to speak to the honest John Molkus.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: An Invalid?—Stop comrad! Young lady and miss march to your apartment!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: With all my heart. Do you think we shall stay here in your tobacco society and suffer ourselves to be smoked.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Come, let us see how mops does.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Unluckily, fate has destined us, not to see any but dogs faces. Exit.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (opens the door) Walk in comrad.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter FREDERICK as an invalid, with a wooden leg and ſeveral ſcars on his face.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Welcome old boy! Do you know me yet?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dont you know George Frolich, of the regiment of Steinacker.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: George Frolich? h'm! have quite forgot him.

sp.speaker: Ered.
sp.p: Do you recollect our encampment before Prague, in the year 1757?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Before Prague? Oh that I know very well. Our regiment was encamped on the Ties Kaberg.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: When the Austrians made an attack on the batteries of Strohhof.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And Prince Ferdinand of Prussia repulsed them.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And when they afterwards made a trial on the side of Wisherad.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And how our grape shot took them in flank.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How the Prince of Lorraine endeavored to surprise us with 4000 men.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And how we sent them back with bloody noses.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: It was a pity that the weather became so bad.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: And that the Moldau swelled to such a height.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To carry all our bridges away.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Right brother! I find that you have been there.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I not there? upon my soul! I was with our battalion when we attacked the Austrians at the windmill of Segeshuk. So we stood, and so we marched towards them, (he marches ſtraight towards the young lady's room) hark there! halloo! where is the enemy! Come out of your holes!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Gently, gently brother! this is not a windmill.— Some women live there.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: God forbid! I would rather attack a party of Croats.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: That's just my way of thinking.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: When I hear of women, I run like the French at Rosback.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: You just think as I do.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I would rather loose my other leg too.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Where have you lost your leg.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: At Collin.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Just the place where I lost mine.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: They may possibly lay together in one grave. The deuce fetch the legs! if the heart is but fresh. Come brother, let us drink together. (draws a bottle out of his pocket.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: With all my heart. The health of old Frederic!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Long live Frederic. (he drinks and gives Molkus the bottle.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: At Collin, under General Hulsen, I helped to attack the burying ground.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I was in the brigade of Manstein.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Then you had to do with the Pandors.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you see the scar on my cheek?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: May the Pandors perish. (he continues drinking.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: At Sweidnitz I was present at the assault of the water fort.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: At Olmutz I fought in the trenches.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: At Gibau we were attacked by Laudon when we convoyed a train of transports.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: In the defiles of Krenau we sweated bravely.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What of Krenau! at Leuthen, there we had warm work.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: But brother, you seem to be young yet, and have been in the whole seven years war?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Brother, I am an old boy, but the wine kept me young. Drink, brother, drink! he that wants to remain young, must drink.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes, yes, must drink. (drinks.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No women, and plenty of wine, that makes fresh blood.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes, yes, plenty of wine. (drinks.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How do you come into this house among the women? I would rather live in the barracks.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: How I come among these women?—I stand here sentry.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: For shame, Comrade!—You stood often sentry at the General's tent, and now over women?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What's to be done comrad?—We must put up with the times. In the field we want two legs, but in winter quarters, one will do.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (feigning to be drunk) Think you so?—No brother, he that meddles with women, must have two legs at least.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (beginning to feel the power of the wine) Two tongues would be better for him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A man with a sound pair of arms, must fight. For that reason I entered into the Hessian service.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Among the Hessians?—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And went to America.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: With one leg!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: See now, brother—I calculated that I had but one leg to loose—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Why then?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Because the other was already buried at Collin.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Upon my soul! You are a sensible fellow—Long life to you!— (drinks)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But I would rather gain three battles on land, than to perish once at sea.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The sea must be terrible wet.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And always drunk—always drunk—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The sea!—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Yes, brother, what am I telling you—For instance, we want to sail this way, but the sea won't—and we are thrown that way— (he staggers towards Nanette's room) Now we want to get upon this tack—but there comes a wave, and throws us straight upon a rock! (he runs against the door with such violence that it cracks open.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: He! he! he! he!—Take care, comrad, you are running on a sand bank.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I think I am fast already.—Heigh! Here! Help! help!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ha!—Ho!—Ha!—I tell you, this coast is inhabited but by women—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Let them come. When I have a glass too much, I never fear them.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I can bear them when wine makes me merry—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I shall fire alarm guns—Piff! Paff! Puff!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Piff! Paff! Puff!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My God, what a riot! You drunken fellows, do you think here is a sutlers tent?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (ſecretly) Lisette! Lisette! I am Baron Willinghorst.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (cries) Oh!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Right, Lisette! You are a pretty sutler's girl.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Miss, come here as quick as possible.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: (enters) What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Here is a drunken man, whom you are to make sober.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dearest Nannette, love plays a comedy.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Ah! Is it possible!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (approaches Molkus) Well Molkus, how is it.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Always upon two legs, my lovely child.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Our minutes are precious. I love you beyond expression.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Is this an old brother soldier?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: We lay before Prague together.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May I flatter myself with hopes?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May I explain that sigh to my advantage?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Can I prevent that?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: You had hot work there!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Piff! paff! puff! here Pandors there Croats.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Will you marry me?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: My mother will never give her consent.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I have never seen a Pandor in my life.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The devil possesses these fellows.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Fly to my arms.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Against my mother's will? never!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: But when a Pandor sees a pretty girl, for instance you, Lisette.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Then he becomes tame like a lamb.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Aye!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To-morrow we will throw ourselves at your mother's feet and obtain forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Those that ask for forgiveness must have transgressed first.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Upon my soul, you are a fine damsel.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If you would love me.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: If you loved me.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Has not my heart betrayed me?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (stroking his beard) Do you think then I hate you?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then flee this night, and to-morrow you are mine forever!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: You hate me not, little rogue?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I am guarded by thousand eyes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Who could see the valiant Molkus, and remain indifferent?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Love will enchant them all into blindness.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: If that's true, then give me a kiss.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: If you promise to marry me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May I make a trial this night, to elope with you?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: To marry? Ha! ha! ha! have never married in my life.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: How will you force yourself through locks and doors?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That's my care.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Try only, we shall live together like doves.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Like doves! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have I your consent?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I trust to you my innocence.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: But the kiss—the kiss.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (kiſſing him) There you have it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (embracing Nannette) Heavenly girl.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (ſeeing it) Aye! aye! comrade!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What is it brother?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: You are attacking Sweidnitz.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The fort is ours!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Victory! let us fire victory! Piff! paff! puff!

sp.speaker: Lady Brumbach
sp.p: (without) Unharness the horses.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My god, the old one is coming!

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Ah, my mother!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Where can I fly to?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: She is at the door.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Victory! the old one comes!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is the window high?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But one story. It leads into the garden.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Adieu, dear Nannette! I shall see you again. (he jumps upon a chair, and thence through the window.)

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Ah! if he but does not hurt himself.

sp.speaker: Malk.
sp.p: Haigh Comrade! Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What riot is this! When the cat is out of the way, the mice jump upon tables and benches.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide) She forgot the chairs.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Victory! The old cat is arrived.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Molkus, are you drunk?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The fellow has but one leg and leaps like a wild goat.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Who gave him to drink?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Go block-head! go to sleep.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (to Liſette) Come then, little bride, let us go to sleep.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Are you crazy?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: To-morrow, dear Molkus, to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: To-morrow, the regimental priest shall come— "John Molkus! Will you have this girl?"—Yes.— "Lisette Pertness, will you marry John Molkus?"

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Yes.—Good night, children, good night, sleep well! (he reels to the window.)

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I am going to look for my comrade.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Your comrade?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (calling out of the window) Holloo! George Frolich! Where are you?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (drawing him from the window) you are mistaken, there is the door.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I can't leave my comrade in the lurch.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What is all this?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: He is drunk.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Drunk or not drunk! he stormed the Water Fort at Sweidnitz, consequently—

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (draging him to the door) Consequently you must go to sleep.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: We must first fire victory.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Fire without, as much as you please. (She ſhoves him out of doors.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (without) Piff! Paff! Puff!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Has any body been here?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Not a soul.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Look at me (Nannette raises her eyes timorouſly) can you swear?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Lisette, can I swear?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p:
Why not? I should like to know, how any body could have entered here? Has not this drunken fellow been constantly sitting at the door▪ Has he not smoked us with
his tobacco and brandy, it stinks here just like a guard-room.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Why did you not remain in your room?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: We were going to meet you, when we heard the carriage.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: How is Mops?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: He is in a sweet slumber.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: It is late, children, go to bed.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Shall I not undress you first, Madam?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Shall I read the evening prayers to you, Mama?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: No. You shall go to bed. I intend to set up. There is a fine star light night, I have some knowledge of Astronomy, I know the great Bear, and the Orion.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide) Alas! Where is our Sattelite of Venus!

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: (kissing her mother's hand) Good night, dear Mama.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Go my child, endeavour not to sleep so much. Think of the affront you have met with to-day, and you have cause enough for a sleepless night.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: An affront? To me?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Have you already forgot that impudent fellow and his powder bag?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Ah! I did not know that a girl can be affronted by an offer of marriage.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: He marry you? a boy just from school, and a girl hardly bigger than her doll?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I am sure Mama, he wants to marry me.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Indeed? and how do you know that?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I—I suppose so—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I suppose that you are a fool.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: To marry? What are you thinking, Miss? They come, they gaze; they love; they burn; first a flame, then coals, then cinders. Woe to the girl, that makes a cinder barrel of her heart.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Right Lisette, explain that chapter a little to her before you go to sleep, away to bed!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: To bed! to bed!

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.p: The hour of trial is approaching. Obedience, Mr. Piffelburg, submission—he that shuns a cold, will he, as husband fetch the Physician at night, when I am taken ill? Accommodating to me he shall be, but not accommodated. In short, if I have given him the garden key in vain, then door and heart shall be shut against him. He that mounts a galley the third time to be chained to the oar; does not deserve compassion.—I'll put out the lights, that I may perhaps over-hear his talking to himself, (ſhe extinguiſhes the lights.) Confess it only, Salomeh, you wish a good termination of the Romance, for the disagreeable circumstance of your being already forty-eight—hush!—in the name of God. I hope I am not overheard! alas! old age has traitors enough, without the help of the tongue.—What is that? Why this rustling of the trees, near the window?—Methinks I hear the creeking of the window.—Indeed! I feel by the drawft, that it opens more and more.—Should Piffelburg—to give me a token of his obedience—endeavour to creep through the window?—that would be charming—hush? hush!—I must see the end of that.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: FRED. (Opens the window, and puts his head through it.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
