Hush! hush!—all is quiet—all darkness—I may venture— (he creeps through the window, the wooden leg is left behind.) Here I am again. But what more?—
It is so dark that one can't see the hand before ones face.— On the right hand is the door, (he fumbles about) hush! hush!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (in the back ground) hush! hush!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: He answers— (in a low voice) is any body here?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (with a diſſembled voice) I am here.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My beloved?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O hasten to my arms.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Here! here!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Where? where? (he runs towards the voice and at laſt embraces Madame Brumbach.) I hold you in my arms and no power of earth shall tear me from you again!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (crying) Ah! this is not Piffelburg.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (leaving her) Damnation! this is not Nannette.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Help! help! thieves! robbers!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This will become a funny affair.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What is the matter here, is it the witches' holyday?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: By heavens! it is the old one.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: But comrade, how do you come by this sound leg▪

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who are you sir? what is your business here?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (in conſternation) —I have long since wished for the honor of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And therefore you had to come through the window?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If I durst tell you every thing—If I could be so fortunate, to speak to you a few minutes in private.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (to Molkus) Set your candle down and be off with you.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Do but tell me comrade, where you got this leg from? procure me mine too.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Go to sleep, I command you.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The fellow is a sorcerer.— (he puts down the candle, and goes off.)

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Now sir, we are alone.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (aſide) What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I am anxious to know, how it happens, that you appear here, at the very hour in which I expect Baron Piffelburg? and that in so strange a manner.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Baron Piffelburg?—for that very reason Madame— because I know that the power of your attractions, extend themselves even to a man, to whom I am in the nearest relation.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Nearly related to you? how is that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah! Madame! you see in me a ball of fate, an unfortunate child of love.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A bastard.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Baron Piffelburg is my father.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Your father?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My mother was his housekeeper, and something more. After her beauty faded away, he turned her off, the cruel man; she went into the wide world, and maintained her and me by begging.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: This is the consequence when we leave the path of virtue.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I grew up and entered into military service.—I have fought in Russia against the Turks, and in Flanders against the French—The scars on my face are proofs of my valour.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Was not your father moved by that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I have wrote to him many lamentable letters, but never received the least support.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (aſide) the poor young fellow, I pity him.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Chance at last brought me to this city—I learned, that my father met with the fate of all who see you, Madame; that he loved you, that he adored you.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A little less poetry, I beg.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I heard at the same time, that you were the most amiable, and beneficent Lady, that ever was formed by the maternal hand of Nature. A ray of hopes raised itself in my heart, and I resolved to direct myself to you.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: But why just through the window? and did you not, in the darkness, speak of a beloved?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Will you pardon me, that, deprived of all hopes, ever to be allowed to approach you, I directed myself to Lisette, your chambermaid? and that I intended this night to consult with her on the means, to gain your feeling heart in favour of a wretch who wishes to have to thank you for the alleviation of his miseries?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Then it was Lisette whom you expected?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Whom else, Madame? It is Lisette that painted to me in heavenly colours the amiable picture of your virtues; it is she who inspired me with hopes, that you would use the power you have over my father, in favour of a youth, who feels himself less miserable, since he is so near you.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (aſide) The young man speaks well. (loud) I promise you, to do something for you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (kiſſes her hand) Rejoice, poor Frederic! the beautiful Baroness Brumbach takes your part.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I expect your father every moment. You shall be witness—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No! no! I will ascribe it all to your power, and nothing to the impulse of nature. Permit me to take my leave.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: No, no, you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My father might—at the first sight of me—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I engage to put his head to rights.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I know him—he is headstrong.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Don't you know, that love can lead lions by a silken thread?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Here I am. Hail and lightning! this is a cold night.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (aſide) Now, impudence, assit me?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Welcome, Sir. You are a fine bird. You never told me that you had children?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I? Children?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: That a son of yours ranges about in the world, a prey to misery?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: A son? of mine?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Indeed, a fine young man, well deserving to be taken notice of.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Are you jesting with me?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Be ashamed! do you know this youth?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I have never seen him in my life.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (at his feet) Yes, my father! Do not deny the voice of nature! recognize in me your son, your unfortunate Frederic!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: What the devil! are we playing a comedy?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah! till now it has been a tragedy, it is to you to convert it into a comedy! take me into your paternal arms! let the tears of parental love trickle upon my cheeks.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Young man, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your cruelty will deprive me of reason.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Will you continue to shut up your heart against nature's tender feelings?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: The fellow is a fool, and makes a fool of me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you hear it, Madame? he disowns me! Me, the son of his housekeeper, who loved him faithfully, and took disinterested care of his linen and kitchen. He desires my misery! He desires my death! Cruel father! to-morrow my bloody corpse will be found in the river! to-morrow the cry of woe will fail upon you!—Ha! I already see the devil's claws stretched out to take hold of my poor soul—Away, away with you to hell! (aſide) Stop a little, I'll plague you more yet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And you let him go?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: He may go to the devil! The fellow is out of his mind. Why does the police not confine such vagabonds?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Out of his mind? No, Sir, he spoke very reasonable.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: But, hail and lightning, there is as little reason in this as in an air gun. He that has no housekeeper can have no son, and he that has no son cannot be a father, how?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You deceive me. It is very probable that he belongs to you.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Why then? perhaps because he is a fine fellow?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What reason can he have to pretend to be your son?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: St. Hubertus may know that.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: In the first place you are not rich.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Alas! no.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: In the second you are hard hearted.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: By all the elements! Must we then erect a foundling house, to gain the name of being tender hearted? I cannot bear the hearts, on which every flower makes an impression, and every tear digs a hole.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What advantage then can he expect by such a deception?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I declare it once more, that St. Hubertus may know that better than I. He is a pretty fellow indeed, he has made fine progress in villainy. Who can know what he is aiming at.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: But if he throws himself into the water?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: No danger of that.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And is dead to-morrow?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Then I will be condemned, to shoot sparrows and to dig moles all my life time.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I observe, sir, that you possess more cunning than I expected of you.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: The devil take me, if I have more cunning than a shot of gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Do you know that my chambermaid is acquainted with the young man?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: That I believe. Chambermaids have many acquaintances.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And consequently is able to unmask your hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: My conscience is as blank as my fowling piece.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: We shall soon hear that. (she opens the door of her apartment) Lisette? are you in your bed?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (behind the scene) No, Madame.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Then come here for a moment.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Here I am. What are your commands?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You are a pretty creature, you have nightly rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I, Madame?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You let young fellows come in through the window.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide) Oh Lord! Lord!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: But, this time I'll excuse you, if you will openly confess: Where have you made acquaintance with that young man?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Here in this house—he was so friendly—so complaisant—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And how do you know him to be the son of Baron Piffelberg?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Out with it! I will know all. In short, I will not suffer that such a gallows bird shall declare himself to be my son.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Has he then confessed it himself—that this gentleman is his father?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: He has. He has solicited my protection and called you as a witness.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Well, if he has disclosed the secret himself, I must confess, that he has indeed the honor to be very nearly related to Baron Piffelburg.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: To the devil, but not to me!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: There we have it. Have you evidence Lisette?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: O yes—for—one dare not tell every thing—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Out of the bush!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Perhaps you know his mother?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: His mother?—yes—she is a distant relation of mine.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Now, Baron Piffelburg.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Caltrops! fox draps! wolf's ditches! I'll be shot with peas, if there is a single word of truth in all this gibberish.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: A penitent confession might perhaps have gained my forgiveness. But now—what am I to think? There are undoubtedly more such boys running about in the world— who knows, how many poor deceived damsals are sitting behind their spinning wheels, wetting the flax with their tears for your faithlessness.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I'll be hanged, Madame, if my conscience is not so pure, that I might find a hidden treasure.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: But I should not like to stand in the circle.

div.head: SCENE XIII.
div.stage: Enter FREDERIC (dressed in women's clothes, with a veil over his face.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (to Piffelburg) Have I found you at last, faithless man? Have I at last discovered your clandestine practices?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A new scene indeed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is this the reward for my fidelity and constancy? Is this the way you fulfil your vows?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! have I then entered a mad-house?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Who are you, Madame? What do you want?

sp.speaker: Ered.
sp.p: Pardon, Madame, an unfortunate woman, who has been cruelly deceived. Thousand times has this gentleman vowed to me eternal love, thousand times has he promised to marry me. This ring he gave me as a pledge of his faith.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Is it possible!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Woman! are you possessed with the devil?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So? now I am possessed with the devil? but when you lay at my feet, and coaxed me out of my innocence, then I was an angel.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Satan's angel!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (weeping) And now you throw me from you, now, when I carry the pledge of love under my heart—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Sirrah! another child!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I am petrified.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Long since I have heard, that you walk on uneven ground, but I would not believe it; I took the trouble of watching you, and when you at midnight stole out of the house like a thief, I followed you.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Woman! I'll tear your scandalous tongue out of your throat!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Stop, Sir! I take her under my protection.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dear Madame! you are generous and beautiful, your sight alone can serve the traitor as an excuse.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Satan! come but out doors, I break your neck, and put you in Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There you hear it.—Even his own flesh and blood he wo'nt spare. Ah! poor me! what shall I do! I dare not go from here, he will murder me!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Yes, you hawk! that I will! you crows' face! you night-hawk!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Be tranquil, Madame, you shall be protected. Go meanwhile to my daughter, there you are perfectly secure.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah! Madame! fame does not say too much of you, when it describes you as the most generous lady.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Conduct her in Lisette, (secretly) and let her out of the back door, here is the key.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (stifling a laugh) Very well, follow me Madame.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (to Piffelburg) Farewell, you tyrant! ah! you still beloved traitor! (Goes with Liſette into the apartment.)

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: So it goes, when one does not remain quietly in one's bed at midnight.—'Tis all witchcraft. Satan has let loose seven evil spirits.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You want to persuade me that the devil is the father of your bastards?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: The devil suffocate me on the first cross road, if I ever have seen that woman in all my life, no more than that villain, who with all the powers of hell, wants to be my son!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: In short sir, all is over between us.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Do but examine first.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What is there to examine? here a son and there a a mistress.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: The one deserves the gallows, and the other the wheel.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Then, to be sure, their maintainance would not cost you any thing.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Ah! Madame! what a misfortune!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Ah! I can say no more!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Is the woman in a fit?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: She has run away.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: And has taken the young lady with her.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Now we are paid for all.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What? speak!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: When I opened the back-door—as you ordered—she all at once threw away her cloak and veil—and then I saw she was a young gentleman—and then I saw him take Miss Nannette in his arms, and like lightening ran off with her.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: And the young gentleman was with child, ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Couldn't you cry then?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I was going to cry—but he drew a dagger—and held it to my breast—and said my death should be the consequence, if I made the least noise.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Oh what an unfortunate mother am I! What shall I do! My child! my only child!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Have I not told you before? it's all deceit.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Ah my dearest Baron Piffelburg! if you love me— hasten! fly!—in pursuit of the robber!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: So! I thought it was all over between us?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I have wronged you, forgive an unfortunate deceived mother.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Will you marry me then, if I fetch him back again?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Yes! yes!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Done! I'll see whether I can scent the hare—he will take a round-about course, but I will follow him to the bed, where he jumped out from. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Away Lisette! call Molkus! he also shall go on the high road, and you too! take the patrol with you! get the gates shut! run! run!—ah! I could tear the hairs from off my head! (runs to her apartment)

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Yes, if she had any to tear out. (Exit laughing.)

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: (THE COMMON HALL IN THE INN. Night.)
NANNETTE comes running from Frederic's chamber. FREDERIC follows her.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: NO, I wo'nt stay in your room.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I don't know why, but my feeling tells me, that it is unbecoming.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is it then more becoming here?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: In an open hall, where people pass every moment there is no danger.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What danger then is there in my room?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I don't know, but when I am alone with you there, my heart beats. It beats here too but not so much.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well? and is the heart-beating a sin then?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I don't know, but I had a governess, who used to say; shun every thing that makes your heart beat and drives the blood to your face.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She most likely, had a faded heart and not a drop of blood.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Pray, fetch a light.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Are you afraid of ghosts?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Sometimes, but not when you are with me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Why then shall I fetch a light?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Why! why! you continue asking why? and I do not know it. But there is something within me that whispers: beg him, to fetch a light.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But what says that something, if I refuse it you?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Then it becomes uneasy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your bright eyes, give light enough for me.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Whoever seeks darkness, wants to do wrong.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Can we do nothing wrong at candle light.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: No, we are ashamed of ourselves.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Consider only, dear Nannette, if we had a light— three steps from here lives your Mama, how soon we might be surprised and betrayed.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Ah my God, I almost wish to be betrayed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You don't love me then?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: O yes, I am heartily attached to you; but that we are so alone together, is certainly not right.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have you not promised to become my wife? and may not husband and wife be alone together.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Yes, husband and wife may, but we are not husband and wife yet.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A few hours only, and we shall be so, as soon as daylight appears.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Ah! I wish it would appear!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your impatience will spoil all. We shall be sure you will be torn away, and lost to me forever.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I shall remain faithful to you, indeed I shall.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have compassion on my impatience, come to my room.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Rather into the street, or the market.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Singular girl! If a girl runs away with a man, she may as well go to his room too.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Have I then run away with you? ah! that was stupid of me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you repent that step?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Almost. What will you think of me? You must believe me to be very thoughtless; indeed it is the first time I have run away with a man.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (smiling) I willingly believe you.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: You have surprized me so, that I know not how it happened.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: All disquietude will be gone to morrow. Just now something comes into my head, which will obviate your delicacy. I will lead you to my tutor's apartment.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: To the apartment of a man?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Of a man of fifty.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Whom I know not.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I shall stay with you.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: But he will sleep, and we shall still be alone.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Droll girl; he has a night lamp before his bed.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: And if he wakes?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Then I present to him my bride.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: It would be better he did not sleep at all.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (smiling) Agreed. I will wake him.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Go then.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Accompany me.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: No, you must wake him first, and then he must fetch me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Even that—but I do not like to leave you here alone—yet it is done in two minutes. Do not move, and if any one pass the hall, keep your breath. (he enters the room.)

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: (alone) Have I then any breath left? It is to me as if I could not repose at all—I tremble like a leaf—Why did my governess say; The wicked only tremble?—But my heart tells me, that love is nothing bad.

sp.speaker: LADY BRUMBACH
sp.p: (comes ſoftly out of her room.) Methinks I heard somebody talk, (liſtening) No, all is quiet—My God! how much anxiety and grief this wicked girl of mine, causes me!—Let me only get her again, I will soon confine her in a Convent. (re-enters her room.)

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: In a Convent?—Ah! then I'll rather go to the Baron's apartment.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter FREDERIC, and FELIX in his night gown.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Here, dear Mr. Felix, here is the dear bashful girl.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Frederic! Frederic! What have you done?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ask rather, what will you do? I will marry her.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: After such an action, you muſt indeed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My God, I do not desire it otherwise. Do but turn your lamp and look at her face.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Dear strange sir, have pity on my innocence! be my father!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: A father, my child, is easier deceived than a mother.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: (to Frederic) Do you hear it? he reproaches me. Ah? it goes through my heart? I will return to my mother. She will confine me in a Convent—there I shall constantly weep—but here I can't be happy either.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Felix! listen to the voice of the purest innocence! if ever you have loved me, assist me!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I pity your weakness, still more the inexperience of this good girl. I will assist you, but on one condition.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I agree to any.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: You must at day-break throw yourself at her mother's feet, and beg for her blessing.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Willingly! willingly!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Till then this young lady remains under my protection.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Ah, now I become easier.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Will you trust yourself to me?

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: With joy! you appear to be so good, so honest, I have confidence in you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Go then, dear child, into this room, I follow you immediately.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Go Nannette, and slumber if you can.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I slumber? feel how my heart beats. I felt so but once in my life, when I had the small-pox, and then I could not sleep at all. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do not leave the poor timorous girl alone.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: But one word more, young man—Maiden's honour is like polished steel—a breath, and it looses its lustre.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Not by the breath of love.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Just by that the soonest. This girl seems to be a spotless lamb. If this should be one of your love intrigues; if you were capable, to sacrifice her after three days to a fancy—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Never!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I hope it not, for I know your heart—But I must declare to you, that in such a case, I would immediately quit you, and call your father's curse upon you!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To-morrow she is my wife!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: As soon as the mother consents, she is your wife.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: LADY BRUMBACH (comes once more to the door▪)
div.p: It still seems to me—My God! a ghost! (shuts the door behind her.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This was the old one.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: How am I—Methinks I know the voice.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have you ever heard the crocking of the crows.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Now I'll go to the poor timorous creature. You stay meanwhile, where you can, and do not appear before me till you have gained the maternal consent.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That will be a difficult matter. Yet I must make the experiment—When a powerful prince has an appetite to a province, he begins, by taking possession of it, and the treaty of peace follows of course. Nannette is in my power, that's the main point:—And if Lady Brumbach was the devil's grandmother, her claws shall never tear her from me again.—But what shall I do with myself just now? To my bride I dare not go, sleep, I cannot, and pray, I will not. Nothing is so tedious, as the languor of a lover—The hour creeps, we follow it, we pass it, we wink—all in vain! It creeps the pace of snails.— We want to carry it forwards—Ah! it is as heavy as lead. We put wishes to the carriage, they won't draw; whip it with the nettles of impatience, it won't proceed. Accompanied by prayers and curses, it at last arrives at its destination. The lover embraces his bride—and then the next hour runs as if it was mad—No cry of halt can stop it, no wish overtake it! it runs along! along into eternity!—and sometimes it takes love away with it.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: LISETTE (comes timerously through the middle door.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is there not something moving? (he coughs.)

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: H'm! h'm!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That's a woman's cough, (in a low voice) from what beautiful breast does this h'm proceed?—No answer?— Hush? hush!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Hush! hush!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What beautiful lips does this hush come from?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Is it you, Baron?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Baron? there are many Barons, which of them do you mean?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Baron Wellinghorst.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You have hit it. And you?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I am Lisette.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah Lisette! is it you? come, let me embrace you. You come quite apropos, to help me passing my time.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Where is my young Lady?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Secure enough with my Tutor. But where are you driving about, at midnight?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Lady Brumback has sent me out to search for you.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have you found me then?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Do not jest. I know not what to do.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Stay with me.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Bring me to my young lady.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That won't do.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She is with my tutor, an old peevish man.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My God! Shall I then return to lady Brumbach?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Who compels you then?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: She will scold, bawl, grumble, and heaven protect me, if she finds out that I have favoured your roguery.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Be tranquil. I declare you, in this solemn hour, by virtue of my matrimonial power, as the well advised chambermaid of my wife, from this hour to all eternity, and as a token of my sincerity, I give you this kiss as earnest money.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (oppoſing him) This is stolen money; it belongs to your bride.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Take it, I recoin this piece of money every minute.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: It is good for nothing, where love does not make the impression. Jest aside, Baron, I enter into your service. 'Tis but just, for you have brought me into this dilemma.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Well then, I will get you out of it.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: That is not the question. But where can I go to now? now, this moment? On the right hand is hell, (pointing to Lady Brumbach's room) and on the left Satan. (pointing to Frederic.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How would that be, if you was to go to purgatory till morning?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: See, there in the wardrode, I use to get my hair dressed. Some old cloaks are hanging there. In one corner stands an umbrella, and in the other a lanthern. Will you stay there till morning?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Rather than with the old witch.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Come then, I'll carry in a chair, and at daybreak Nannette shall relieve you.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: A fine opportunity to reflections of penitence.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: As long only as one is alone.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: My God, it is as dark here as in a grave.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your black eyes will give you light.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I am not a cat, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There, sit down upon this chair, and be as quiet as a mouse.—Good night my pretty Lisette. (he claſes the door) Now I'll creep about the house, like a ghost. I will hear every mouse behind the paper hangings, and every worm in the wainscoat. [Exit.]

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Enter MOLKUS, coming through the middle door.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p:
I would rather pursue a hare than a lover who runs away with his girl. A race horse has but four legs, but such a fellow has wings.—I have been running about half the night
in wind and rain. My sound leg is tired, and the wooden one covered with mud. I can do no more. For me they may run to the Arabian deserts, and eat Locusts, like St. John.—If I go to the old dragon and make my report, I shall jump out of the frying pan into the fire. I'll rather encamp here for the night, no matter how it goes. (he ſits down upon an arm chair) Hang it! it is as soft as if it had been made for a gouty man.— Thank God, I can have the gout but in one leg—Ah! now I feel again comfortable and warm — (gaps) and powerful sleep is creeping on. — It an't a bed, to be sure, — but after such a fatigue — When in the seven years war, — I stood on an out-post — there sometimes I would — lay on my musket — and nod— nod—. (he murmurs a few more unintelligible words, and then falls asleep.)

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: All my greyhounds wo'nt overtake this hare. That's an old fox, who has often been at it. We must encircle him and hunt him up, or he will get off clear, and eat the chicken up, without mercy. A whole hour I have been upon the trot through thick and thin. What have I gained by it? wet feet, pain in my ears, and the gout in my arms.—Shall I let the old one wash my head into the bargain? No, no, I'll stay here till daylight, and attempt to sleep a little on one of the chairs. (He fumbles about, and touches the chair on which Molkus ſleeps.) Aye, aye, here is a chair. Now let us try whether an old huntsman, after such a fatigue, can fall asleep without rocking. (He ſits upon Molkus's lap.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (wakes) Heigh, there! The night-mare has got hold of me!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! what's that?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: (encircles him with both his arms) I have him! I have him!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Satan, let me go!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: The robber is caught!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: All good spirits, praise our Lord!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Bring light! light!

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: You are the prince of darkness!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I shan't let you go; where is the young lady?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Satan's claws, leave me!

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Enter FREDERIC, (dressed as a butler, humpbacked, stuttering, with a plaſter over one eye, and a candle in his hand.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What noise is this? Gentlemen, what are you about?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Ah, Molkus! is it you?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Ah, Baron Piffelburg! is it you? I thought you were that robber.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I thought, you were the devil.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Why did you sit down on my lap?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I would rather be on Abram's lap than sit again on yours. I am so terrified that all my limbs tremble!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am only employed in this house since yesterday, but if it be every night so noisy, the devil take such employ! what do you want here at so late an hour?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I was running after the eloped young lady.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Hopping after her you meant to say.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I did the same.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Have you caught her then?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Ask me rather whether I could outrun a hare?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Who knows in what ambush she has fortified herself?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But if I should know it?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You must not betray me.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Let us hear then.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The young people are still here in this house.

sp.speaker: Piff. and Molk.
sp.p: Where? Where?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Do you see the dining room?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There they are not.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Proceed, proceed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: And there is the wardrobe—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There they are neither.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Scoundrel, do we want to know where they are not?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Patience! patience! if they are not yet there, they may come to it.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Think you then, they will—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I heard whispering. When all is quiet in the house, the young gentleman intends to put her into the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Into the wardrobe? a fine ambush.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But the young lady objects to it. She says it was too dark there, too solitary.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Where then does she mean to stay?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: In the dining room.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Then we must be in ambush there.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But the young gentleman insisted on the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Then we must take our post there.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: But the young lady insisted on the dining room. No, said he, no, said she, yes, no, yes.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! who then carried the point at last?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: See now, I think so: be attentive. If you both go into the wardrobe, and the young lady does not come there—

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: Then we wait in vain.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Quite right. But if you both go to the dining room, and the young lady goes to the wardrobe—

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Then we are hum'd.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You have guessed it. But if one of you hides himself here, and the other there, then she cannot escape you.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Bravo! it is to me as if I had caught her already.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Only keep her fast.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Be not concerned.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I will take post in the dining room.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Do so, and at the first noise I'll come to your assistance.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: That's right. The allied army forms a line.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Off with you to the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Give me the light.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: God forbid! If a light was seen, nobody would enter.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: It is not haunted, I hope?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! By fine girls sometimes.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Fine girls are not always good spirits. (He goes to the wardrobe.)

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So. Now you may sit there till broad day-light. (looks at his watch) Three o'clock. Creep, creep, creep, you leaden hours! But a time will come, in which I will dance with you through the world!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (coming timorously out of the door) Thank God! there is light. Tell me, my good friend, is not this house haunted?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I have heard a strange noise.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: The cats.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I have seen a figure, a hideous ghost.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (aſide) She most likely was before her looking glass.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I have sent out all my people; be so kind to stay with me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Cheerfully, Madame, what company could be more agreeable than yours?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Have you heard any thing of my daughter?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Of your daughter?—Well—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: You shrug your shoulders? speak!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I know very well—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What do you know?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: That she has run away.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: That I know too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I met them on the stairs.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And have not stopped them?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If I was to stop every one I meet on the stairs—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: But my God! you well saw—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What have I seen? a young lady with a young gentleman. Nothing new, I am sure, in an inn.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Where are they gone then?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Between us, I believe, they are in this house yet.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: In this house? My good friend, I'll reward you, if you assist me in catching them.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I do it willingly without reward. Please to go to the dining room.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There on the left hand you will find a door, leading to a long passage, where a lamp is burning.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You then go to the end of the passage, where you will find a small stairs.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: There I step up?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No, no, you step down, and then you are all at once in the yard.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And what shall I do there?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What you please.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Blockhead! but where shall I find my daughter?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You cross the yard, and leave the cow stable at your left.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: If I wanted an ox, I had not far to look for it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: At the farther end you will see the laundry.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Is she there?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: God forbid!—but at the side of the laundry—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Well? at the side of the laundry?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is a Mangle-house.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: There she has hid herself?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Perhaps so.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: At last! I will put on my cloak. My friend, you shall go with me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (alone) I accompany you, old dragon? No, I am not inclined to wade with you in the dung puddle. I have disposed of all my good friends, now they may find the way themselves. (he puts the candle on the table, and runs off.)

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (returns in a fur cloak) Here I am again— Now? Where is the fellow?—Indeed, he left me and his reward. No matter, since I know where to find my runaway daughter. Dining room, passage, stairs, yard, cow stable, laundry, Mangle-house,—right!—shall I take the candle with me, or leave it here? In the dining room it's dark, but in the passage burns a lamp. Better I creep in the dark, and appear suddenly among them, like Peter the great among the conspirators, if only I do not meet the ghost. (She goes into the dining room. Soon after Molkus is heard crying.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I have her! I have her!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Help! Help!

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: What help! Mama will help soon enough. Out of the hole!

sp.speaker: MOLKUS
sp.stage: (holding Lady Brumbach in his arms, throws the door open with his foot, and cries whilst he carries her out.)
sp.p: I have her! I have her!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (recognizing Molkus) Molkus, what possesses you?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.stage: (looks at his prize, lets her go in consternation, and remains standing before her with staring eyes.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Are you drunk again?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: It seems so; bewitched at least.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: (within) I have her! I have her!

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Help! Help!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: He has got hold of her, if the devil does not play him a trick too.

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: (within) Resist as much as you please, I shall hold you fast.

sp.speaker: PIFFELBURG.
sp.stage: (holding Liſette in his arms, pushes the door open with his foot, and cries, bringing her out)
sp.p: I have her! I have her!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Baron Piffelburg, what does that mean? What are you doing with my chambermaid?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.stage: (Looks at his prize, drops Liſette, and stands staring.)

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: On what chace have you been?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Seemingly on the witch chace.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p:
I am quite petrified. All three of you I have sent
out, and now find you at home? My pretty Baron Piffelburg, what business have you in the wardrobe?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: I was on the look out.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And you, Molkus, what had you to do in the dining room?

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I lay in ambush.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And you, impudent girl?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: I—I wanted to mend the laces, in which your ladyship tore holes at the last ball.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: To mend laces in the dark? fine indeed!—And you, Baron Piffelburg, are not ashamed at all?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: And for what then? That the devil plays hide and go seek in your house?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Is this the friend in need? is this your love? instead of pursuing my daughter, I find you with my chambermaid in a suspicious corner?

sp.speaker: Piff.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! the devil fetch you and your daughter! I am tired of it! The moment I put my feet in your house, Satan sets all his evil spirits loose. There comes a damned fellow and calls me father; another scoundrel pretends to be my mistress, and at last, when I hold your daughter fast, she converts herself into Lisette. Is it not all a comedy? It can't be worse on the Block's mountain A place which Poets say to be the rendezvous of Witches.. No, Madame, I am your humble servant. I will rather eat potatoes and turnips between the ruins of my castle, than to marry into this family of witches.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Ah! what an unfortunate woman I am! My daughter is eloped; my lover runs off; all, all leave me in the lurch.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I see clearly, that the spy has deceived us.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: But come. I know where Nannette is concealed. Take the light, Molkus, follow me through the passage, into the yard, into the cow stable, into the laundry, into the Mangle-house.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: God preserve us! she is crack-brained.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (throws himself at the feet of Lady Brumbach.) Stay, Madame, and excuse the love, which is the cause of all this confusion.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Who are you sir? What is your desire?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am the man, who ran away with your daughter.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And you venture to appear before me?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Permit me to make good my transgression. I am Baron Willinghorst, the only heir of a rich house—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And if you were the heir of the Emperor of Abyssinia—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I love your daughter, your daughter loves me—

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: In a Convent between two walls she shall atone for her disobedience.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: No, this feeling heart will not forever be immoveable; those lovely lips were made, but to pronounce blessing.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Flattery? away with you, sir!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pardon!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Curse!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Your daughter at least.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: As soon as I have broke her neck.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Will you drive me to despair.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Yes, sir! I wish you would go to hell in despair.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You are not serious.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (diſdainful) I do not jest with children.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Child? I am then indeed your child?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: My satan you are! be off!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I shall not rise, till you give me your beautiful hand as a token of reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Then you may lay there till the end of time.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Well Madame! I shall lay here till the sun extinguishes, and the earth is torn from its poles.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Be sparing with your hyperboles. I shall never give my daughter to a man, who begins his suite by depriving an innocent girl of her honor.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Of her honor?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Who intended to cover my black hair with grief and shame.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: With shame, Madame?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: I hope you won't endeavour to make me believe, that it was honorable for a young girl to run away with a young fellow at midnight, and to hide herself with him, God knows where?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: You wrong me. Miss Nannette is under the protection of a venerable old man, my Tutor.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: So? a pretty Tutor!

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: He himself will assure you, that your daughter's honor and innocence have been treated with the greatest delicacy, and that I even durst not see her during the whole night. (he rises and opens the door of his apartment.) Come Nannette! come dear Mr. Felix! assist me in softening the obdurate maternal heart.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: (crying loud) Ah! my husband!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: By all the devils! my wife!

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Is it you, Charles?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Is it you, Salomeh?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What means all this?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Are you not dead yet?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Alas! no.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide) A tender meeting.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Have I not cited you in all the newspapers?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Did not I go out of your way?

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (aſide) Now she has all at once a husband.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: (to Felix) If I understand right, this lady is your wife?

sp.speaker: Felix.
sp.p: Alas! yes!

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: (to her mother) Dearest mama! is this gentleman my father?

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Alas! yes.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: How moving and edifying!

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: (embracing Felix) My father! What unexpected joy!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: My good child, you help me to support the presence of your mother.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: O now we are all relieved at once? Dear Mr. Felix, from you I expect my sentence.

sp.speaker: Felix.
sp.p: Yes, dear Frederic, she is yours. I know your heart. The wine is yet fomenting, but it is good. Indeed, dear Nannette, you often will have to exercise your patience.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I'll have patience, dear papa.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Very well, Charles, you may do as you please, she is your daughter. But you are mistaken if you think that I shall ever be your wife again. I have cited you in all the papers, and we have been formally divorced for your malicious desertion, as the lawyers call it. The consistory has wrote full twelve sheets about it, and put a large seal under it.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: I have not the least objection against it. Take, if you please, three husbands more, and get divorced three times more. My property you may keep, for the sake of the amiable daughter you have given me.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: We may meet in company with propriety?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: O yes.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: And I never shall make the least mention of what I suffered with you.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Then, mes chers enfans, I will not withhold from you my blessing any longer.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: God's blessing be upon you! and with tears in my eyes, I conjure you—Do not follow the example of your parents.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Dearest Nannette! you are mine!

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Dear Father!

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Now children, you must separate. You, Nannette, go with your mother, and you, Frederic, follow me.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: I am not sleepy at all.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: To-morrow, children, to-morrow your wishes shall be crowned.—Good night, Madame.

sp.speaker: Brumb.
sp.p: Good night, sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Sleep well, dear Nannette.

sp.speaker: Nann.
sp.p: Sleep well, dear Frederic.
FELIX, and Lady BRUMBACH (make the usual courtesies, Frederic and Nannette throw kisses to each other; all go to their apartments.)

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: A singular occurrence.

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: Now Molkus, you wanted to marry me last evening.

sp.speaker: Molk.
sp.p: I was drunk then. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: Liſ.
sp.p: (alone) So? and is not the young gentleman drunk too?—Aye, aye, I fear, in four weeks, he will be sober enough.
